raw_text:
Parmalat bank barred from suing
 
 Bank of America has been banned from suing Parmalat, the food group which went bust in 2003 after an accounting scandal.
 
 The bank - along with investors, auditors and the group's managers - wants damages for being a victim of fraud at the hands of the Italian firm. But a judge has barred Bank of America and two auditors from the case. The bank, and Italaudit - formerly the Italian arm of auditor Grant Thornton - face lawsuits and possible prosecution. A second auditor, Deloitte & Touche, has also been banned from the case. Grant Thornton - now rid of the Italian unit at the centre of the case - is still being permitted to sue, as are Consob, Italy's stock market regulator, hundreds of small investors and Parmalat's new managers. Parmalat collapsed in December 2003 after it emerged that the 4bn euros ($5.2bn; £2.8bn) it supposedly held in a Bank of American offshore account did not in fact exist.
llama3.2:1b: Parmalat bank barred from suing, Bank of America and auditors banned due to fraud allegations against Parmalat's Italian firm.
The bank seeks damages and possible prosecution for being victims of the scandal.
llama3.2:3b: Bank of America has been barred from suing Parmalat over an accounting scandal that led to the Italian food group's bankruptcy in 2003.
The bank and two auditors, Grant Thornton and Italaudit, face lawsuits but were banned from the case by a judge.
Deloitte & Touche remains permitted to sue, along with Consob and hundreds of small investors, as well as Parmalat's new managers.
gemma2:2b: Bank of America and its affiliated entities (auditors Italaudit, Deloitte & Touche) have been banned from suing Parmalat following an accounting scandal that led to the company's collapse.
However, Grant Thornton is still permitted to sue, along with Consob, small investors, and Parmalat's new managers.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Bank of America was banned from suing Parmalat for failing to pay claims in an accounting scandal, but both Parmalat's auditors and the Italian arm of Grant Thornton remain barred from lawsuits involving the group.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Bank of America barred from suing Parmalat, which collapsed due to an accounting scandal, following the ban on investor lawsuits and possible prosecution.
qwen2.5:3b: Bank of America and Italaudit (formerly Grant Thornton), along with investors, auditors, and Parmalat's managers, have been barred from suing Parmalat for being victims of fraud.
The ban affects the bank and two auditors, while Grant Thornton is still allowed to sue as are Consob, small investors, new managers, and Parmalat itself.
This decision comes after Parmalat collapsed in 2003 due to an offshore account discrepancy.
opencoder:1.5b: The bank barred from suing Parmalat, the food group which went bust in 2003 as a result of an accounting scandal.
The bank, along with investors, auditors and its members decided that it was fraud at their hands and therefore they brought lawsuits to the case.
The group's members also sought damages under the ban.
Two other audits were banned from the case by a court decision.
The Supreme Court ruled in favor of both the Bank of America and Deloitte & Touche, while Consob upheld theBan for Gran Thornton's claim.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should be:
Parmalat bank barred from suing
Bank of America has been banned from suing Parmalat, the food group which went bust in 2003 after an accounting scandal.
The bank - along with investors, auditors and the group's managers - wants damages for being a victim of fraud at the hands of the Italian firm.
But a judge has barred Bank of America and two auditors from the case.
The bank, and Italaudit - formerly the Italian arm of auditor Grant Thornton - face lawsuits and possible prosecution.
A second auditor, Deloitte & Touche, has also been banned from the case.
Grant Thornton is still being permitted to sue, as are Consob, Italy's stock market regulator, hundreds of small investors and Parmalat's new managers.
Parmalat collapsed in December 2003 after it emerged that the 4bn euros ($5.2bn; £2.8bn) it supposedly held in a Bank of America offshore account did not in fact exist.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Bank of America was banned from suing Parmalat in 2003 due to an accounting scandal where the bank, investors, auditors, and management were implicated in fraud involving Parmalat's collapse in 2003.
Despite their claims for damages, a judge barred Bank of America and two auditors from the case.
Other companies like Deloitte & Touche, Grant Thornton (now based elsewhere), Consob, and Parmalat's managers also faced lawsuits or potential prosecution.
tinyllama:1.1b: Parmalat, the food group, was barred from suing Bank of America and two other audiotors (who had been previously allowed to sue) as well as investors, auditors, and managers.
The ban stems from a fraud scandal at Parmalat's Italian arm in 2003, which led to the collapse of the company.
The lawsuits were also halted against Deloitte & Touche, Grant Thornton, and Consob as well as other small investors and new managers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In the recent financial scandal involving Parmalat, banking giant Bank of America was banned from suing the food group and its Italian subsidiary due to a court order.
This decision comes as no surprise, considering that both Bank of America and investors have been accused of being victims of fraud.

Despite being barred from pursuing the case against Parmalat and its Italian subsidiary, bank clients may still face lawsuits or possible prosecution for their involvement in the alleged accounting scandal.
phi:2.7b: Bank of America was barred from suing Parmalat due to fraud, while two auditors and the bank itself faced lawsuits and possible prosecution.
Grant Thornton is still permitted to sue as they are a separate entity from the Italian unit at the centre of the case.
A second auditor, Deloitte & Touche, has also been banned.
Consob, Italy's stock market regulator, hundreds of small investors, and Parmalat'S new managers can still sue.
orca-mini:3b: Bank of America has been banned from suing Parmalat, which went bankrupt due to an accounting scandal in 2003.
The bank and two auditors face lawsuits and possible prosecution as victims of fraud at the hands of Parmalat and its Italian subsidiary.
Another auditor, Deloitte & Touche, has also been banned from the case.
hermes3:3b: Parmalat, banned from suing Bank of America and two auditors (Deloitte & Touche, Italaudit), over fraud case; Grant Thornton, Consob, small investors allowed to sue.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Bank of America has been prohibited from suing Parmalat, the Italian food group that went bankrupt in 2003 due to an accounting scandal.
The bank, along with investors, auditors, and managers, seek damages for being a victim of fraud.
However, a judge has barred Bank of America and two auditors (Italaudit and Deloitte & Touche) from participating in the case.
Grant Thornton, the former Italian auditor, is still allowed to sue, while hundreds of small investors and Parmalat's new managers can also pursue legal action.
The collapse of Parmalat occurred when it was revealed that a $5.2 billion (€4bn) offshore account in Bank of America did not actually exist.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Bank of America has been barred from suing Parmalat over the 2003 accounting scandal that led to the food group's collapse.

The bank, along with two auditors, Italaudit and Deloitte & Touche, has been excluded from the case, while Grant Thornton, Italy's stock market regulator Consob, small investors, and Parmalat's new managers are still allowed to sue.
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was revealed that the €4bn it claimed to have in a Bank of America offshore account did not exist.
Bank of America and Italaudit also face lawsuits and possible prosecution.
stablelm2:1.6b: Bank of America has been barred from suing Parmalat due to accounting scandal and fraud allegations.

However, two auditors have been banned from the case, while Parmalat's new managers and various other parties are also involved in lawsuits or possible prosecution following the collapse of the food group in 2012.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Bank of America and two auditors—Italaudit (former Grant Thornton) and Deloitte & Touche—are prohibited from seeking damages for their alleged losses due to Parmalat's 2003 fraud, which led to the company's collapse.
Consob, Italy's stock market regulator, along with hundreds of small investors and Parmalat's new managers, can still pursue claims against Parmalat and the defunct auditors.
Parmalat had falsely claimed to hold 4 billion euros in an offshore Bank of America account, which turned out to be non-existent upon investigation.
